captions.text:
I wasn&#39;t going to bring up the Coronavirus
thing again, I mean, the site&#39;s called The

Escapist, not &quot;The Constant Reminders Of Our
Inevitable Hubristic Doom.&quot; Besides, it&#39;ll

pretty seriously date the videos in a month
or two when the virus goes away forever and

everything returns to normal and all the dead
people come back to life and there&#39;s a rainbow.

But now I have to talk about Resident Evil
3, a game about society descending into chaos

because of a viral pandemic. It could only
have been less fortunately timed if the zombies

ate toilet roll instead of brains. So, after
the success of the RE2Make last year, the

Threemake was something of an inevitability,
I suppose, partly because the process of remaking

Resident Evil 2 just doesn&#39;t feel complete
until it&#39;s had a slightly lazy sequel knocked

out of it. Resident Evil 3 follows Jill Valentine,
the marginally less bulbous of the two protagonists

of Resident Evil 1, who is stuck in Raccoon
City during the outbreak depicted in RE2 and

can&#39;t leave for another three days for reasons
I wasn&#39;t entirely clear on, maybe that&#39;s when

her holiday in Tijuana starts. But she&#39;s suddenly
having to move up her plans when a giant half-sucked

jelly baby wrapped in bin bags called Nemesis
breaks down her door fixing to grab her and

throw her at walls over and over again to
no apparent effect for about six hours.

It wouldn&#39;t be Resident Evil or an Alien film
unless the evil corporation is prioritising

being evil above actions that make any actual
sense so Nemesis was sent by the Umbrella

corporation specifically to kill Jill and
indiscriminately destroy and murder anything

between him and Jill in case anyone should
find out about how Umbrella indiscriminately

destroys and murders things, all of which
smacks of middle-management decision-making

to me. Jill must explore the ruined city trying
to help survivors in the moments when Nemesis

isn&#39;t throwing her at walls, joining forces
with a mercenary named Carlos who is suffering

from a bad hair day that must be seen to be
believed, he looks like he&#39;s auditioning to

stand in for a bowl of Kellogg&#39;s All-Bran.
Thus ensues gameplay very much like the RE2Make,

funnily enough - explore all the rooms looking
for puzzle items that unlock doors and expand

the space, all the while finding it inexplicably
difficult to shoot encroaching zombies in

the head. The main addition to gameplay is
a dodge move that you can use to get a free

hit on the enemy if you time it right. Although
about half the zombies weren&#39;t properly informed
of this and just grab you anyway.

And then you have to do the minigame where
you mash X, and if you fail you get a zombie

bite, and if you win you also get a zombie
bite but can feel marginally better about

yourself. Whoops, no time to complain about
that, here comes Nemesis again. I don&#39;t know

if its worth analysing the subtext of a game
about a giant muscular man refusing to leave

alone an attractive underdressed lady and
trying to penetrate her with his big floppy

willy of death. She is at least better dressed
than she was in the original, when she looked

like an embarrassing single mother accompanying
her daughter to a roller disco, but still,

Threemake sometimes gives me a Tomb Raidermake
vibe when the amount of shit that gets kicked

out of Jill Valentine starts to border on
the fetishistic. No I don&#39;t think I sound

disingenuous when I get finger waggy about
this kind of thing, it&#39;s not like I jerked

off to it more than once. Anyway, as you might
have guessed from him having top billing and

everything, Nemesis is the big selling point
of RE3, and it is a fucking effective concept
to frame an action horror game around.

Here&#39;s a walking fridge smeared in cat food
who wants you dead, dresses in hefty bags

and as such probably can&#39;t be bought off with
Abercrombie &amp; Fitch gift cards, and every

time you try to kill him he just grows another
layer of cat food. And your chief lines of

defense are two D-cups and a questionably
reliable dodge button. In other words, it&#39;s

the Mr. X thing from the last game except
with the greater narrative weight it probably

deserved. But where Mr. X was a free range
murder man who organically roamed the whole

game environment, Nemesis has his nipples
chained to a milking machine in the ethically

unsound factory farm of linear plot, and let&#39;s
dwell on that lovely image for a moment. All

the fights and chase sequences with Nemesis
feel very scripted, in fact, RE3&#39;s a generally

more linear game. Even more so than the original,
which had this choose your own adventure thing

going on where you&#39;d occasionally be given
a binary choice that would slightly affect

the direction of the plot. Threemake chucks
all that in the bin, possibly because it was

so lame it was entitled to handicapped parking
spaces. But nevertheless both iterations of

RE3 for me represent Resident Evil losing
its impact and starting to just go through
the motions.

Zombies, bizarre locking mechanisms, poorly
thought out character motivations and in the

end you go to a secret underground lab and
fight a giant wall of snot. Jill&#39;s initial

poorly thought out motivation besides avoiding
getting turned into a rissole the size of

a sleeping bag by Captain Catfood is to rescue
a train car full of civilians. But then it

crashes and they all die and Jill moves on
sparing them no more thought than she does

the leftover chow mein that was in her fridge.
Some meandering follows and then her new goal

is to stop the government from nuking Raccoon
City. Basically everyone&#39;s dead at that point

but there are still loads of perfectly good
multi storey car parks. Spoiler alert, she

fucks that up, too, and once again largely
shrugs her way through the grief, but it does

enable her to meander into a secret underground
lab and do the giant wall of snot fight. So

while every Resident Evil game is a load of
fannying about, then giant wall of snot in

a lab, RE3&#39;s fannying about is even fannier
than usual, the wall of snot all the snottier

and more inevitable. If anything recommends
the Threemake it&#39;s that it&#39;s another five-odd

hours of the survival horror gameplay you
may or may not have enjoyed in the Twomake.

And a multiplayer mode, Yahtz. But I&#39;d say
the difficulty is a bit higher generally,

and not always in a way that feels fair. I
was having trouble with those Hunters, the

zombie teenage mutant ninja turtle motherfuckers
who have super armour and move super fast

so if you don&#39;t have a big weapon out they
just slit you open like a bag of maltesers.

And then the game over screen kept bugging
me. &quot;Hey, would you like to switch to a difficulty

setting more suited to your clueless girlish
simpering, player?&quot; That depends, Threemake.

Would you like to be coughing up my pubes
for the next three days? &quot;Oh fine. Here&#39;s

your loading screen tip: Hunters are close
range fighters. Remember to back up and keep

your distance.&quot; Threemake! You&#39;re making me
fight these things in a fucking hospital corridor!

What&#39;m I supposed to back up into, the fucking
vending machine coin return slots? Perhaps

you&#39;d have a better time in the multiplayer
mode, Yahtz. And you know what&#39;s really taking

the piss is that outside the rather anaemic
campaign badly in need of a Mars bar and some

exercise, there aren&#39;t even any other gameplay
modes. No Mercenaries mode, no extra challenges,

I mean, what the fuck were they even working
on this whole time? Probably the multiplayer,
Yahtz, why don&#39;t you play some of it?
Hello, doctor? I&#39;m hearing the voices again.
The ones that keep telling me to hurt myself.
